titleInfo.title: Advances in Nanomaterial Engineering for Electrochemical Biosensing and Electrocatalysis Applications

mods:mods.abstract: Nanomaterials and electrochemistry are two highly interrelated fields that have achieved significant advancements in recent years, due to their synergistic potential. Nanomaterials offer highly advantageous properties for electrochemical applications such as electrochemical sensing and electrocatalysis, including enhanced surface area, biocompatibility, electrical conductivity, and high catalytic reactivity. This thesis aims to encompass the development of controlling gold nanostructure morphology for electrochemical aptasensing technology and to assess carbide nanomaterials for meeting industrial requirements as active and stable oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts. The first part of this thesis in Chapter 3 focused on the preparation of gold nanostructured surfaces to enhance the performance of electrochemical aptasensors. Nanostructuring gold surfaces through various electrodeposition techniques allowed precise control of gold morphology features, impacting surface area enhancement, aptamer packing density, sensor signal change, stability, and sensitivity. This exploration of gold morphology effects on electrochemical aptasensor performance aims to finely optimize miniaturized sensors for future applications such as in-vivo sensing and in-vitro cellular studies. The second part of the thesis in Chapters 4-6 focused on studying the OER electrocatalytic behavior of monometallic (Fe, Co, Ni), bimetallic (FeCo, FeNi, CoNi), and trimetallic (FeNiCr, FeCoNi) nanocarbides. The feasibility of low-cost, stable, and highly active anode materials for efficient OER is critical for improving the performance of electrocatalytic water splitting for chemical energy storage applications. The thermodynamic and kinetic requirements for the OER are the main limiting factors in producing hydrogen, the desired product. Carbon-based materials are widely used in the electrolyzer and fuel cell industries as anode and cathode materials, yet research is lacking on how to enhance catalytic efficiency with the use of multimetal tuning and understanding the effects of unstable oxide formation for long-term use. Thus, this part of the thesis aimed to explore the role of Fe in tuning carbide catalyst activity and stability for multimetallic compounds, particularly the effects of Fe oxide on catalyst degradation.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Robert. A. Lazenby, Professor Directing Dissertation; Steven Lenhert, University Representative; Michael G. Roper, Committee Member; Qing-Xiang Amy Sang, Committee Member.
